aicpa-topic.title: Leveraged Buyouts and Bridge Loans

body.p: 5.109 As noted in FASB ASC 940-325-05-1, a broker-dealer may make investments in the form of equity or provide financing to another entity in connection with financial-restructuring transactions. These investments may take many forms, including a direct investment or an investment in an entity (sometimes referred to as a bridge entity) that is established for the purpose of accumulating funds from several sources sufficient to make the investment. FASB ASC 940-325-30-1 and 940-325-35-1 state that investments in the form of equity or financing provided to another entity in connection with financial-restructuring transactions should be initially and subsequently measured at fair value. As stated in FASB ASC 940-810-45-1, a majority-owned entity that is not in the scope of the “Variable Interest Entities” subsection of FASB ASC 810, Consolidation, and in which a parent has a controlling financial interest, should not be consolidated if the parent is a broker-dealer, and control is likely to be temporary.
